TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in PERSON . He used to run a car repair garage .

He formed that view , inter alia , on the basis of proceedings in which ORG had , in a decision of DATE ( no . BACARDINALD/CARDINAL/CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) , ordered him to demolish a building ( a tank ) on his property on the ground that it had been erected illegally . Those proceedings , following the applicant 's complaints , were discontinued by ORG on DATE in decision no . CARDINAL in which it held that the building had in fact been erected legally . The applicant also referred to a decision by ORG DATE refusing him planning permission . On DATE the Wałbrzych Governor , reversed that decision following an appeal by the applicant and granted planning permission ( decision no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) .

“ Open letter

BA-CARDINAL-D/CARDINAL/CARDINAL/CARDINAL - CARDINAL the proceedings were discontinued , after it was found that the building had in fact been erected lawfully ;

I think that the above few examples should prompt you to consider whether you should withdraw . I have CARDINAL question : WOULD YOU LIKE A PERSON WHOM YOU ELECT TO LOCAL GOVERNMENT TO DEAL WITH YOUR CASES AS ILLUSTRATED BY THE ABOVE EXAMPLES ?

CARDINAL . On DATE Mr PERSON brought an action against the applicant in ORG ( PERSON ) under section CARDINAL of the Law on Elections to Municipal Councils , ORG ( “ LAW ” ) . He sought an order requiring the applicant to correct untrue information that had been circulated in the open letter and to publish a correction in the local newspapers PERSON and PERSON and other newspapers to which the open letter had been originally addressed . Mr PERSON also requested that the court order the applicant to issue an apology . Finally , he requested that the applicant be ordered to pay PLN MONEY for the benefit of a charity run by ORG in GPE and to pay ORG CARDINAL to the claimant in damages .

CARDINAL . On DATE ( at TIME ) ORG gave its decision . It ordered the applicant to publish in the local newspaper LOC and in a letter to the claimant a statement that he had included untrue information in his open letter of CARDINAL DATE and the following apology :
“ I apologise to Mr. PERSON for defamatory statements about him which were included in my open letter to him of DATE ” .
The court also ordered the applicant to pay PLN MONEY for the benefit of the charity run by ORG in GPE and FAC CARDINAL,CARDINAL to the claimant in damages .
CARDINAL . ORG held as follows :
“ The court established the following facts :

The defendant sent to the claimant and a large number of persons and institutions his open letter dated DATE , in which he alleged that the claimant , while the Head of ORG , had been an inept , and sometimes malicious manager and had frequently broken the law . He alleged that a document had been lost from a case file examined by ORG , that in another case documents had been forged , and that the claimant , with a view to intimidating the defendant , had instituted proceedings and ordered him to demolish a building ; [ that ] for DATE he had maliciously refused to grant planning permission , [ that ] he had resorted to a lie in the CARDINAL DATE edition of ' Gazeta Wrocławska ' , and , finally , that he had instituted enforcement proceedings , infringing the defendant 's rights , and thus broken the law and abused his authority by demanding that the defendant execute a non - existent obligation ( see the defendant 's open letter of CARDINAL DATE ) .

On DATE ORG discontinued the investigation in case no . ORG CARDINAL/CARDINAL concerning a lost document since no suspects could be identified . It did not determine when or where a copy of the decision of ORG dated DATE had been lost ( copy of the decision to discontinue the proceedings of CARDINAL DATE ) . ...

On DATE ORG instituted proceedings of its own motion in respect of the construction of a tank on the defendant 's property , following complaints from neighbours . Those proceedings were discontinued by a decision of DATE , since it was established in the course of the proceedings that the tank had been constructed legally ( ... , decision of ORG of DATE , decision of ORG of DATE ) .

On DATE the defendant and his wife made an application to ORG for planning permission in respect of a shop / office , a manual car wash , a tank , .... These administrative proceedings were terminated by ORG decision of CARDINAL DATE ....

On DATE Gazeta Wrocławska ' published an article ' War with decisions ' , in which the claimant mentioned a sewer junction located at the intersection of FAC and FAC in GPE . In the defendant 's letter published in ' Gazeta PERSON ' of DATE he stated that there was no sewer junction in the place indicated by the claimant .

By a decision of DATE ORG ordered the defendant and his wife to produce the documents necessary to obtain permission to use a building . On DATE ORG executed the order of DATE in lieu of the debtors and at the debtors ' expense . On DATE ORG discontinued the enforcement proceedings ...
The court considered :

The content of the open letter dated DATE from the defendant to the claimant , which was received by a large number of people and institutions , constitutes a ground for allowing the application under section CARDINAL of LAW . That letter contains untrue information about the claimant and the authority of which he is the head . The [ court 's ] assessment of the evidence showed that it was not true that a document had been lost from the case file in one of the cases examined by ORG , that documents had been forged , or that ORG had sought to intimidate the defendant or had acted maliciously against him . Nor is it true that the claimant violated the defendant 's rights by instituting enforcement proceedings , in the course of which he broke the law and abused his authority . The investigation carried out in respect of the [ lost ] document did not establish the time or place of its disappearance . The defendant did not prove that the maps prepared by ORG were forgeries or that ORG had acted improperly , still less , maliciously . These are the defendant 's impressions which are arbitrary and unsupported by evidence . All of the proceedings which were pending before ORG were instituted and carried out on the basis of applicable law and the defendant exercised his right to appeal against individual decisions . It was established that the proceedings were conducted speedily , as evidenced by the dates on which they were instituted and on which they ended . As regards the claimant 's statement in ' Gazeta Wrocławska ' the court found credible his claims that the statement had not been approved beforehand and so might be inaccurate and that the claimant could not speak about a sewer which had existed in the place he had indicated .
In these circumstances , the court finds the application founded and , pursuant to section DATE subsections CARDINAL , CARDINAL , DATE , DATE and CARDINAL of LAW , rules as in the operative part ”

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant complained to the President of ORG that he had been refused access to the official record of the hearing of DATE . CARDINAL . At TIME on DATE ORG allowed the applicant access to the case file .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant filed an appeal with ORG ( Sąd Apelacyjny ) and requested that the decision of ORG be quashed .

CARDINAL . He submitted that his open letter did not amount to electoral campaigning . He relied , inter alia , on LAW and submitted that his critical remarks concerned Mr PERSON as the head of an administrative authority . The criticism was based on shortcomings in the administrative proceedings in which the applicant was involved , as evidenced by numerous documents , relevant administrative decisions and statements of higher administrative authorities and of ORG . Furthermore , the applicant contested ORG finding that the information contained in the open letter was thoroughly . Further , he submitted that at the hearing ORG had prevented the applicant from making comprehensive submissions in reply to the claimant 's lengthy arguments and refused to admit evidence confirming the truthfulness of the statements contained in the open letter .

CARDINAL . The applicant disputed ORG order to pay damages to ORG and argued that the claimant had not proved that he had suffered any damage . In respect of the order to make payment to the institution run by ORG , he denied that it was a charity . The applicant complained that ORG had allowed the claimant 's application in its entirety and made orders to pay damages and to make payment to a charity at the maximum end of the scale provided for by law . Further , the applicant referred to the fact that after the hearing before ORG his access to the case file had been impeded , despite the fact that an appeal had to be lodged within TIME after the firstinstance decision was pronounced . Finally the applicant made detailed submissions with a view to proving the accuracy of the factual statements contained in the open letter .
CARDINAL . NORP The local elections took place on CARDINAL DATE . Mr PERSON was not elected .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant 's appeal . It also made an order for costs against the applicant for ORG CARDINAL . ORG held as follows :
“ The appeal is unfounded .

The proceedings provided for under section CARDINAL of LAW are aimed at protecting electoral law and ensuring the proper conduct of the electoral campaign by preventing infringements of the personal rights of those standing for election ... , which could affect the result of the elections .

ORG correctly found that the defendant had clearly infringed the personal rights of the claimant as a candidate for local government office by his open letter to the claimant that was sent to various authorities and individuals .

The content of the letter portrayed the claimant in an unambiguously negative light as a candidate for the local council and was aimed at preventing him from being elected . Contrary to the appellant 's assertions , in order to achieve that aim it was not necessary to openly discourage [ the voters ] from voting for a particular candidate . It was enough that a recipient of information about a candidate should come to such a conclusion , which , given the open letter 's content , was very likely .

The court concurs with ORG findings that the defendant did not prove that his allegations against the claimant were true and so justified his criticism . In fact , the allegations related to decisions issued by ORG and should not have been equated with the claimant as such . A legal right of appeal lay against the decisions [ and ] in most instances the defendant obtained favourable rulings .

Against the background of those decisions , the applicant 's categorically negative assessment of ORG and the attribution of responsibility to the claimant as a person managing the ORG , coupled with the fact that this was made public were unwarranted and unjustified in law . The facts of the case appear to indicate unequivocally that the defendant transferred to the claimant an aversion to ORG he had developed because of dissatisfaction with CARDINAL of its decisions ; he had used this for the purposes of electoral propaganda , and this [ situation ] was rightly considered by ORG as amounting to a breach of section CARDINAL of LAW .... “

CARDINAL . In DATE local elections the applicant was elected a local councillor for ORG .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL provides as follows :
“ GPE shall ensure freedom of the press and other means of social communication . ”
LAW , which lays down a general prohibition on disproportionate limitations on constitutional rights and freedoms ( the principle of proportionality ) , provides :

“ Any limitation upon the exercise of constitutional freedoms and rights may be imposed only by statute , and only when necessary in a democratic ORG for the protection of its security or public order , or to protect the natural environment , health or public morals , or the freedoms and rights of other persons . Such limitations shall not violate the essence of freedoms and rights . ”
LAW guarantees freedom of expression . It states , in so far as relevant :
“ Everyone shall be guaranteed freedom to express opinions and to acquire and to disseminate information . ”
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the Law of DATE on ORG , ORG ( ORG wyborcza do rad gmin , rad powiatów i sejmików województw ) ( “ the LAW ” ) provided , in so far as relevant :

“ § CARDINAL . If posters , slogans , leaflets , statements or other forms of publicity or campaign materials contain untrue data or information , candidates standing for local election or representatives of electoral committees shall be entitled to apply to ORG for an order :
( CARDINAL ) for the confiscation of such materials ;
( CARDINAL ) restraining [ the defendant ] from publishing such data or information ;
( CARDINAL ) for the correction of the information ;
( CARDINAL ) requiring [ the defendant ] to apologise to the aggrieved party ;
( CARDINAL ) requiring [ the defendant ] to pay MONEY to a charity ;
( CARDINAL ) requiring [ the defendant ] to pay to the claimant up to FAC CARDINAL,CARDINAL in damages .

§ CARDINAL . ORG , sitting with a single judge , shall examine the application referred to in DATE within TIME in non - contentious [ civil ] proceedings . [ ... ] . The court shall , without undue delay , serve on the interested party referred to in § CARDINAL , the regional electoral commissioner and the person required to execute the court 's decision a decision which will bring the proceedings in the case to an end .

§ CARDINAL . An appeal to ORG shall lie against the decision of ORG provided it is lodged within TIME from the moment the decision was delivered . ORG , sitting as a panel of CARDINAL judges , shall examine the appeal in non - contentious [ civil ] proceedings , under the same procedure and within the time - limit referred to in § CARDINAL . No appeal shall lie against the decision of ORG and its decision shall be enforceable with immediate effect .

CARDINAL . On DATE a bill amending LAW was tabled in the PERSON . Under the terms of the bill , subsections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of section DATE of LAW were to be repealed with a view to aligning that LAW with the LAW of DATE on Elections to the PERSON and the ORG of GPE ( ORG wyborcza do PERSON i do PERSON ) . On DATE the PERSON amended section CARDINAL of LAW by repealing subsection CARDINAL . However , subsection CARDINAL of section CARDINAL of LAW remained unchanged .

CARDINAL . NORP Until DATE the conduct of parliamentary elections was primarily governed by the Law of CARDINAL DATE on Elections to the PERSON of GPE ( PERSON wyborcza do PERSON ) . Section CARDINAL of the Law of CARDINAL DATE provided for comparable summary proceedings to those referred to in section CARDINAL of LAW . However , that provision laid down a substantially lower ceiling ( PLN CARDINAL,CARDINAL ) on the amount which a defendant could be ordered to pay to a charity or for non - pecuniary damage . LAW DATE on Elections to the PERSON and the ORG of GPE ( ORG wyborcza do PERSON i do PERSON ) , which entered into force on DATE , repealed the LAW DATE . Section CARDINAL of the latter PERSON , which regulates summary electoral proceedings , does not provide for any pecuniary awards to be granted against a defendant .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG gave a decision in case no . I ACz CARDINAL/CARDINAL in which it stated :

“ CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the LAW applies to factual statements contained in the materials pertaining to an electoral campaign . It does not apply to conclusions or opinions based on those factual statements . Only factual statements have an objective character . Every opinion is subjective depending on the viewpoint of the person holding it .

CARDINAL . No one can be prevented from expressing his views and making comments as long as he or she does not infringe the rights of others . However , even an infringement of personal rights that fails to meet the conditions specified in section DATE will not qualify the holder of the right for protection under that provision , since it is an exception [ to the general rule ] and thus can not be interpreted broadly . ”
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG gave a decision in case no . I ACz CARDINAL/CARDINAL in which it held :

“ Section CARDINAL of LAW [ ... ] provides an exception to the general rule and so can not be construed broadly . It is applicable solely to untrue information included in electoral materials . It is not applicable to comments and opinions concerning the characteristics of a candidate [ for election ] . If such comments and opinions infringe the candidate 's personal rights , he may seek redress under the general rules [ of protection of personal rights ] , but not on the basis of section DATE of LAW . ”
